questions.question: If I were you, I …………………………… this.
questions.description: When the verb in the if-clause is in the simple past tense, we use would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If you ………………………. red and green, you will get yellow.
questions.description: In the first conditional we use a simple present tense in the if clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: Unless you ……………………….. smoking, you will get cancer.
If you …………………………. your ways, you will land in serious trouble.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If you had called me, I ………………………. come immediately.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If you start now, you ………………………. there on time.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If I learned electronics at college, I ………………………… an engineer.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would / could + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: Unless you stop drinking, you ……………………….. liver trouble.
questions.description: Unless means if not. This sentence can also be written as: If you do not stop drinking, you will develop liver trouble.

questions.question: If you see him, ………………………… him to visit me?
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If you ………………………. into James, tell him that I am getting married.
questions.description: We can use should in the first conditional to suggest that something is very unlikely.

questions.question: If he ……………………… late, we will have to leave without him.
questions.description: Should is possible in the first conditional.

questions.question: What would you do if you …………………….. to lose your job?
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would / could + infinitive in the main clause.
